block.p: Best Bet

The Big Duck, that quaint reminder of Long Island's past duck-farming pre-eminence, opens for the season on Saturday. From 11 a.m. to 3 p.m., there will be a magic show, pony rides, children's games, a vintage-car parade, petting ducks, music and, for the second year in a row, the ''Big Duck Quack-Off'' to crown the best quackers in the crowd. Now operated by Suffolk County, the retail store-turned-museum, which is on the National Register of Historic Places, is on Route 24 in Flanders and will be open from 10 a.m. to 5 p.m. daily through the summer. (631) 852-8292.

Still Celebrating

Holiday weekend festivities are spruced up today by the ''Fourth Annual Community Mosaic: Street Painting Festival'' in Riverhead. In addition to turning pavement into art, participants can catch an art exhibition and musical performances from noon to 5 p.m. in and around the grounds of the East End Arts Council on East Main Street. The day will be capped by the unveiling of the ''Community Wall Project'' at 4 p.m. and, from 5 to 7 p.m., a ''Sunset Swing'' family picnic with music by the John DeWitt Trio. (631) 369-2171.

At 1:30 p.m. at the Wantagh Bay Yacht Club, there's the Ninth Annual Blessing of the Fleet (516) 571-7460. The carry-overs today include the ''11th Annual Spring Festival'' at Old Bethpage Village Restoration, Round Swamp Road, with 19th-century music and dance, military drills, crafts demonstrations, period ''Base Ball,'' a crafts show and sale and the ''23rd Annual Historical Exhibition of Long Island Horticulture'' from 10 a.m. to 5 p.m. and again tomorrow. (516) 572-8401.

In Huntington today, the ''28th Annual Renaissance Faire,'' complete with battling knights, medieval theater, music and crafts, pony rides and food, continues from 11 a.m. to 6 p.m. at the Unitarian Universalist Fellowship on Brown's Road. (631) 427-9547.

In Southold, the Historical Society still holds its ''Founders Weekend Celebration'' from 10 a.m. to 4 p.m. with a Civil War re-enactment and crafts demonstrations on the museum grounds on Main Road. (631) 765-5500.

Tomorrow the Cathedral of the Incarnation, on Cathedral Avenue in Garden City, holds its 47th Annual Memorial Day Fair, with crafts, games, rides and an organ recital, from noon to 4 p.m. (516) 746-2955. The Lake Ronkonkoma Historical Society holds a special program at its museum on Hawkins Avenue from 10 a.m. to noon. (631) 467-3152. And the Museums at Stony Brook on Route 25A reduce admission fees to $1 for everyone from 10 a.m. to 5 p.m. (631) 751-0066.

Finally, for those who love a parade, Memorial Day is right up everyone's patriotic alley tomorrow from Elmont (along School Street at 9:30 a.m.; 516-437-6248) to Lake Ronkonkoma (Raynor Park at 10 a.m.; 631-467-6686) to East Hampton (Main Street at 10 a.m.; (631-324-0362).
Something Funny

The Westhampton Beach Performing Arts Center begins its new season today with Joy Behar, the former English teacher with a masters degree from the State University at Stony Brook who has turned a wry, caustic take on life and love into a hit comedy career. Now a co-host on ABC-TV's ''The View'' as well as a standup comic and author, Ms. Behar takes to the stage on Main Street following the opening act, Wali Collins, a popular New York comedian, who appears at 8:30 p.m. In weeks to come, the center will welcome Dionne Warwick, June 23 and 24; Janis Ian, July 2; Bobby Short, Aug. 19, and Barbara Cook, Sept. 2. (631) 288-1500.
Armstrong Tribute

The Town of Hempstead will throw a 100th birthday party for Louis Armstrong on Wednesday. Doing the honors are two original members of Armstrong's band: the bassist Arvell Shaw and the pianist Marty Napoleon. In addition to playing the music associated with Satchmo, the musicians will reminisce about their relationship with him and discuss his career and contributions to jazz. The concert is at 8 p.m. in Levittown Hall on Levittown Parkway in Hicksville. (516) 292-9000, extension 382.
Farm Fresh

The Long Island Growers Market is in business again, bringing fresh, local produce directly from farmers to the shoppers at seven markets throughout the Island. In Islip, at the Town Hall parking lot, and in Locust Valley, at the railroad parking lot, the markets are open from 8 a.m. to 1 p.m. on Saturdays. Next Sunday brings the opening of sites in Huntington, at the Elks Club parking lot, and Lynbrook, at the railroad station parking lot, also from 8 a.m. to 1 p.m. The markets in Riverhead and Port Jefferson begin on June 15, and in Patchogue on July 7. For a complete schedule, call (631) 323-3653.
Southold Arts

The Arts in Southold Town makes its presence felt in this season of beginnings on Saturday with a concert by Philip Cutlip, baritone, and Mary Phillips, mezzo-soprano. The duo perform arts songs and operatic arias at 8 p.m. at Southold High School, off Main Road. On Sept. 3, the group stages its ''Sixth Annual North Fork Jazz Festival.'' (631) 734-7696.
Jewish Films

With eight entries in the offing, the Sid Jaconson Jewish Community Center is dividing its ''Seventh Annual Milton B. Pinck Jewish Film Festival'' in two paarts. Although the documentary ''Life and Times of Hank Greenberg'' will be shown on June 22 at 8 p.m., at the Hillwood Commons Lecture Hall on the C. W. Post campus of Long Island University in Brookville, the emphasis will be on fictional features. ''Man Is a Woman,'' a French comedy tagged the ''Jewish 'Wedding Banquet,' '' opens the series on Thursday at 5 and 8 p.m., and ''Yana's Friends,'' an Israeli comedy about Russian immigrants, follows at 5 and 8 p.m. on June 15, and ''Kadash,'' the controversial Israeli drama, again at 5 and 8 p.m., on June 28. The festival switches to the J.C.C., on Forest Drive in East Hills, with four Monday entries, July 10 through 31, including ''Yidl in the Middle: Growing Up Jewish in Iowa,'' July 24. (516) 484-1545.
Anniversary Tour

The Roslyn Landmark Society stages its 40th anniversary house tour on Saturday. This time out, the nine buildings include two of the homes featured on the first tour, the Eastman House, circa 1815, along with the 1680 Van Nostrand-Starkins House, the oldest home in Nassau County, which is now a museum, and a private home overlooking Hempstead Harbor with one room containing its original turn-of-the-century fabric wallpaper and trim. Before the tour, from 10 a.m. to 4 p.m. , there is a parade at 9 a.m. along Main Street of guides in period dress, a string band, antique fire truck, vintage car and horse and wagon. (516) 625-4363.
Hitting the Trails

Don't look now, but National Trails Weekend is coming up and, of course, will be marked on the Island. The festivities, this year focusing on the Paumanok Path, the 125-mile hiking trail that is to connect Rocky Point to Montauk Point, begins on Saturday with a hike at Laurel Valley County Park in Noyack at 1 p.m. Come Sunday, there will be activities along some of the 105 miles completed: things like hikes at 11:30 a.m. at Murphy County Park in Manoville; at 1 p.m. at Hampton Hills County Park in Hampton Bays, and at 9 a.m. from Third House to Oyster Pond in Montauk, followed by a ''Rough Riders Historical Demonstration'' at 11:30 a.m. at Third House. For a complete schedule, call (631) 854-4980.
Free Choices

FRIDAY -- ''The World Goes Round,'' the Broadway revue showcasing Kander and Ebb tunes from ''Cabaret,'' ''Chicago'' and ''Kiss of the Spider Woman,'' comes to the Plainview-Old Bethpage Library on Old Country Road in Plainview via Plaza Theatrical Productions at 8 p.m. and will be repeated on Saturday. (516) 938-0077.

SATURDAY -- It's ''Teddy Bear Hospital Day'' at the Nassau County Medical Center on Hempstead Turnpike in East Meadow. So from 10 a.m. to 3 p.m., youngsters can bring their stuffed animals and dolls to the cafeteria to play hospital for the day and be entertained and edified. (516) 572-6055

The Long Beach Historical Society joins forces with the local library to stage ''Antiques: Trash or Treasure,'' inviting folks to bring one item for evaluation at 2 p.m. at the library on West Park Avenue. (516) 432-7201.
